org.mfg.mdb.demo

Class Demo_02_PriceMDB

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.mfg.mdb.runtime.MDB<Demo_02_PriceMDB.Record>
      • org.mfg.mdb.demo.Demo_02_PriceMDB

  • public final class Demo_02_PriceMDB
extends MDB<Demo_02_PriceMDB.Record>

    This class provides the API to manipulate Demo_02_Price files. Here you will find the methods to modify and query the Demo_02_Price files.

    An MDB file does not contain any meta-data, it is just raw data, one record next to the other, every sinlge byte is part of the data, however, this class contains the required information to "understand" the files format. Important, do not try to access files created by other classes because you will get an unexpected behavior and corrupted data.

    This is the schema this "driver" class understands:

    Demo_02_Price definition

    Demo_02_Price
    Column Type Order Virtual Formula
    time INTEGER ASCENDING No
    price LONG NONE No

    Demo_02_PriceMDB API

    Now let's see the operations you can perform using this class on Demo_02_Price files:

    Data Insertion

    As you know, in MDB you cannot insert a record in the middle of the file, all the data you add to the file is at the end of it, for that reason we named Demo_02_PriceMDB.Appender to the component in charge of this function. So to add data to the file you have to request an appender: 

     // To connect to an MDB file, the best is to use
 // the "connect" method of the session.
 // In the next examples, we will asume you know it.
 
 Demo_02_MDBSession session = ...;
 Demo_02_PriceMDB mdb = session.connectTo_Demo_02_PriceMDB("demo_02_price.mdb");
 
 // request the appender.
 Demo_02_PriceMDB.Appender app = mdb.appender(); 

 // set the appender values
 app.time = ...;
 app.price = ...;

 // add the record
 app.append();

 ...

 // You can repeat this operation for each item you want to add to the file.
 // Important, is possible that some of these records are yet in the memory buffer
 // so to writes them to the file, you have to flush the appender:

 app.flush();

 ...

 // When you are sure you do not want to add new records, close the appender.
 // The close method also write the pending records to the disk, 
 // so it is not needed to call the flush method.

 app.close();

    So use the method appender() to get the appender, and use the methods Demo_02_PriceMDB.Appender.append(), Appender#append(Record) and Appender#append_ref_unsafe(Record) to add the records.

    Data Query

    We provide different APIs to retrieve data: cursors, selection methods and List wrappers. All of them are based on cursors, so it is important you understand how cursors work.

    Cursors

    There are two type of cursors:

    • Demo_02_PriceMDB.Cursor: sequential cursor.
    • Demo_02_PriceMDB.RandomCursor: random access cursor.

    Both cursors have a particular function and you must use the more appropiate depending on the problem.

    Sequential Cursor

    This is the common cursor, it retrieves all the records from a start position to an stop position. The API is very simple, in the following example we print the data from "start" to "stop": 

     Demo_02_PriceMDB mdb = ...;
 long start = ...;
 long stop = ...;

 // request a sequential cursor from start to stop
 Demo_02_Price.Cursor cursor = mdb.cursor(start, stop);

 // iterate the records from start to stop
 while (cursor.next()) {
        // print the content of the current record
        System.out.println("Read "  
                        + cursor.time + " "
                        + cursor.price + " "
                );
 }
 // important always close the cursor
 cursor.close();

    As you can see it is very simple, just to highlight that you should close the cursor when you stop using it. A cursor creates certain OS resources that should be released as soon the cursor is not needed anymore, also in certain operating systems like Windows, you cannot delete the underlaying file until it gets released.

    See the Demo_02_PriceMDB.Cursor javadoc for more details.

    Random Access Cursor

    This cursor provides random access to the file. It is possible to implement a random access method using sequential cursors (open it, read a record, and close), but a Demo_02_PriceMDB.RandomCursor is the API we provide to perform this task in a more efficient way.

    Let's see this API with an exmaple: 

     Demo_02_PriceMDB mdb = ...;

 // request a random cursor
 Demo_02_PriceMDB.RandomCursor cursor = mdb.randomCursor();

 // read record at position 10
 cursor.seek(10);
 System.out.println(cursor.toRecord());

 // read record at position 34
 cursor.seek(34);
 System.out.println(cursor.toRecord());

 // remember always to close the cursor
 cursor.close();

    In our experience, many times you would like to keep alive a random access cursor until the session gets closed. In this case, we recommend to "defer" the cursor. A deferred cursor is not more than a cursor that is closed automatically when the session is closed. See the MDBSession.defer(ICursor) javadoc for more information.

    MDB uses random access cursors to implement other APIs with a higher level of abstraction like the MDB.record(IRandomCursor, long) method and the lists. Now we want to focus on the "record" method. It is very easy to use, the previous example can be re-implemented in this way: 

     Demo_02_PriceMDB mdb = ...;
 // read record at position 10
 System.out.println(mdb.record(10));

 // read record at position 34
 System.out.println(mdb.record(34));

    Is it simpler right? And it performs very well, yet a random cursor is a bit faster but you can use the "record" if you have a deadline, just do not use to retrieve sequential, in that case remember to use a sequential cursor or one of the "select" methods (we explain later these methods).

    Something to highlight about the "record" method implementation, it creates a random-deferred cursor per thread, so it i safe if many threads call it at the same time.

    Index Search

    TODO: Documentation is coming...

    Data Update

    MDB provides two type of methods to update the values:

    • Update a unqiue row. It re-writes the content of the whole record. It is available for tables without array definitions.
    • Update a particular column or a unique row. It re-writes only that field of the record. It is available only for non-array columns.

    You see in both cases it updates only one record at the same time, and the value to replace should be primitive. Also remember virtual columns are not updated because its values are computed automatically, they are not stored physically.

    The API is simple: 

     Demo_02_PriceMDB mdb = ...;
 // the index of the record you want to update/replace.
 long index = ...;

 // the new values                                                                              
 int new_val_time = ...;
 long new_val_price = ...;

 mdb.replace(index 
                , new_val_time
                , new_val_price
                );

    If you want to update just one column of the record, then you may use the following methods:

    • replace_time(long, int): To replace the time value.
    • replace_price(long, long): To replace the price value.

        public void replace_time(long index,
                         int value)
                  throws java.io.IOException
        Update the record at the given index, but only the column "time" is updated. If you like to update many fields of the record then use replace(long , int, long), but if you want to update just one column, use this method because it is faster.

        value - The new value to set to the column "time".

      • indexOfTime

        public static int indexOfTime(Demo_02_PriceMDB.Record[] data,
                              int key,
                              int low,
                              int high)

        From position low to high, this method finds the index of the record with the time value closer to the given key. This method uses a binary search algorithm (like Arrays.binarySearch(...)), so it assumes all the records are ordered by the time order specified in the column definition.

        This method is an utility, it does not search on a file, else in an arbitrary array.

        Parameters:
        data - Array of records.
        key - The value to find.
        low - The index to start the search.
        high - The index to stop the search.
        Returns:
        The index of the value.

      • indexOfTime

        public long indexOfTime(Demo_02_PriceMDB.RandomCursor cursor,
                        int key)
                 throws java.io.IOException
        Like indexOfTime(RandomCursor, int, long, long) but searches on the whole file.
        Parameters:
        cursor - Random cursor used to search the value.
        key - The value to search.
        Returns:
        The index of the value.
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - If there is any I/O error.

      • indexOfTime

        public long indexOfTime(Demo_02_PriceMDB.RandomCursor cursor,
                        int key,
                        long low,
                        long high)
                 throws java.io.IOException

        From position low to high, this method finds the index of the record with the time value closer to the given key. This method uses a binary search algorithm (like Arrays.binarySearch(...)), so it assumes all the records are ordered by the time order specified in the column definition.

        In MDB there is not any type of "indexing" or "automatic sorting" of the data, binary searches is the fast way used to find values. Usually, to retrieve certain range of data, first you get the start and stop positions (with this method), and then you create a cursor.

        Parameters:
        cursor - The random cursor used to find the value.
        key - The value to find.
        low - The index to start the search.
        high - The index to stop the search.
        Returns:
        The index of the value.
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - If there is any I/O error.

      • indexOfTime_exact

        public static int indexOfTime_exact(Demo_02_PriceMDB.Record[] data,
                                    int key)
        Like indexOfTime_exact(Record[], int, int, int), but searches on the whole array.
        Parameters:
        data - The array of data.
        key - The value to search in the array.
        Returns:
        The index of key, or a number < 0 if the key is not found.

      • indexOfTime_exact

        public static int indexOfTime_exact(Demo_02_PriceMDB.Record[] data,
                                    int key,
                                    int low,
                                    int high)
        Like indexOfTime(Record[], int, int, int) but it looks for the exact value, if the value does not exist, returns a number < 0.
        Parameters:
        data - Array or records.
        key - The value to find the index.
        low - The start position of the search.
        high - The stop position of the search.
        Returns:
        The index of key, or a number < 0 if the key is not found.

      • indexOfTime_exact

        public long indexOfTime_exact(Demo_02_PriceMDB.RandomCursor cursor,
                              int key,
                              long low,
                              long high)
                       throws java.io.IOException
        Like indexOfTime(RandomCursor, int, long, long) but it looks for the exact value, if the value does not exist, returns a number < 0.
        Parameters:
        cursor - The cursor used to find the value.
        key - The value to find the index.
        low - The start position of the search.
        high - The stop position of the search.
        Returns:
        The index of key, or a value < 0 if the key is not found.
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - If there is any I/O error.

      • indexOfTime_exact

        public long indexOfTime_exact(Demo_02_PriceMDB.RandomCursor cursor,
                              int key)
                       throws java.io.IOException
        Like indexOfTime_exact(RandomCursor, int, long, long), but searches on the whole file.

      • thread_randomCursor

        public Demo_02_PriceMDB.RandomCursor thread_randomCursor()
                                                  throws java.io.IOException
        Description copied from class: MDB

        Get the random access cursor attached to the current thread. You can use this if you want to reuse the same random cursor. Reuse a cursor is a good idea. Important, this is a deferred cursor, so it is closed automatically at the end of the session, please do not close this cursor yourself, if you want to release the resources associated to a thread, then use the method MDB.thread_forget().

        This method is specially helpful to implement the models of visualization components like charts, because usually the graphical toolkits like Swing and SWT use a unique thread to paint, so the models can reuse the same cursors to query the database.

        Overrides:
        thread_randomCursor in class MDB<Demo_02_PriceMDB.Record>
        Returns:
        Random access cursor
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - If there is any problem accessing the file.
        See Also:
        MDBSession.defer(ICursor), MDB.select(ISeqCursor, long, long), MDB.select_sparse(IRandomCursor, ISeqCursor, long, long, int), MDB.record(IRandomCursor, long), MDB.first(IRandomCursor), MDB.last(IRandomCursor)

      • thread_cursor

        public Demo_02_PriceMDB.Cursor thread_cursor()
                                      throws java.io.IOException
        Description copied from class: MDB

        Get the sequential cursor attached to the current thread. You can use this method if you want to reuse the same cursor. Reuse a cursor is a good idea, just call the ISeqCursor.reset(long, long) method to restart the cursor in a new range. Important, this is a deferred cursor, so it is closed automatically at the end of the session, please do not close this cursor yourself, if you want to release the resources associated to a thread, then use the method MDB.thread_forget(). Let's see an example of how to use this method: 

         SomeMDB mdb = ...;
 long start = ...;
 long stop = ...;
 
 Cursor cursor = mdb.cursor_thread();
 
 cursor.reset(start, stop);
 
 while (cursor.next()) {
        doSomething(cursor);
 }

        This method is specially helpful to implement the models of visualization components like charts, because usually the the graphical toolkits like Swing and SWT use a unique thread to paint, so the models can reuse the same cursors to query the database.

        Overrides:
        thread_cursor in class MDB<Demo_02_PriceMDB.Record>
        Returns:
        Sequential cursor
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - If there is any problem accessing the file.
        See Also:
        MDBSession.defer(ICursor), ISeqCursor.reset(long, long), MDB.thread_forget()
